titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Collection in the Library of Congress
titlestmt.author:
Prepared by Grover Batts and David Mathisen with the assistance of Thelma Queen
Revised and expanded by Laura J. Kells

Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Actress. Chiefly synopses of silent films and scripts of plays, films, and television productions in which Gish did not appear; scripts, some annotated, for productions in which she did perform; letters received by Gish; and legal files.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

persname.part: Duell, Charles H. (Charles Holland), 1889- --Trials, litigation, etc.

title.part: I never sang for my father (Play)

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of Lillian Gish, actress and author, were given to the Library of Congress by Gish, 1970-1980. An additional item was purchased in 1992.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The papers of Lillian Gish were processed in 1980. Additional material was added in 1985 and 2012. The finding aid was revised in 2012.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Items have been transferred from the Manuscript Division to other custodial divisions of the Library. Some photographs, posters, and drawings have been transferred to the Prints and Photographs Division. Maps have been transferred to the Geography and Map Division. All transfers are identified in these divisions as part of the Lillian Gish Papers.

separatedmaterial.head: Other Repositories
separatedmaterial.p: Other papers of Lillian Gish can be found in the Billy Rose Theater Division of the New York Public Library, New York, N.Y.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Copyright in the unpublished writings of Lillian Gish in these papers and in other collections of papers in the custody of the Library of Congress has been dedicated to the public.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Lillian Gish are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, Lillian Gish Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Born, Springfield, Ohio
Made her stage debut
Danced in Sarah Bernhardt's stage production, New York, N.Y.
Began her movie career, working for D. W. Griffith's Biograph Studio, film debut in An Unseen Enemy
Appeared on stage with Mary Pickford in A Good Little Devil
Appeared in the film Birth of a Nation
Appeared in the film Intolerance
Traveled to Europe to appear in D. W. Griffith's film Hearts of the World
Appeared in the film Broken Blossoms

chronitemset.event: Appeared in the film Way Down East
Directed the film Remodeling Her Husband

chronitem.event: Appeared in her last D. W. Griffith film Orphans of the Storm
Joined the Metro-Goldwyn Co.
Involved in litigation resulting from suits filed by producer Charles Duell
Appeared in her first talking motion picture, One Romantic Night
Returned to the stage in the play Uncle Vanya

chronitemset.event: Appeared on stage in Crime and Punishment
Television debut in The Late Christopher Bean , Philco Playhouse

chronitem.event: Appeared on stage in Miss Mabel and The Curious Savage
Appeared in the films Night of the Hunter , Duel in the Sun , Portrait of Jennie , and The Unforgiven
Appeared on stage in The Family Reunion and All the Way Home
Appeared on stage in Too True To Be Good and A Passage to India
Appeared on stage in Romeo and Juliet

chronitemset.event: Appeared in the film The Comedians
Appeared on the stage in I Never Sang for My Father

chronitem.event: Appeared with Helen Hayes in the television version of Arsenic and Old Lace
Published with Ann Pinchot Lillian Gish; The Movies, Mr. Griffith, and Me . Englewood Cliffs, N.J.: Prentice-Hall
Toured Europe, Russia, and United States as lecturer on the art of film
Received Honorary Academy Award

chronitemset.event: Published Dorothy and Lillian Gish . New York: Scribner
Received Handel medallion, City of New York, N.Y.

chronitem.event: Appeared in the films La Boheme and A Wedding
Appeared in the television film Thin Ice
Received Kennedy Center Honors, Washington, D.C.
Appeared in television production of Hobson's Choice

chronitemset.event: Received the Lifetime Achievement Award, American Film Institute
Appeared in the film Hambone and Hillie

chronitem.event: Last film role in The Whales of August
Died, New York, N.Y.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p:
Lillian Gish was a silent film star whose acting career on stage, in motion pictures, and on television spanned more that eighty years. The bulk of the Gish Papers consists of scripts of plays, movie and television scenarios, and synopses of silent films that are part of the
Speech, Article, and Drama File , but the majority of these are works in which Gish did not perform. However, there are scripts, a few of which are annotated, of productions in which she did appear, including the plays All the Way Home , Anya , I Never Sang for My Father , Nine Pine Street , Portrait of a Madonna , The Star-Wagon , and Uncle Vanya ; the movie The Night of the Hunter ; and the television production of Arsenic and Old Lace .

Included in the
Subject File
are papers pertaining to Gish's involvement with groups and organizations such as the America First Committee and the American Academy of Dramatic Arts.

Miscellany
includes financial papers, interviews, printed matter about Gish that includes material about her younger sister, the actress Dorothy Gish, scrapbook pages featuring printed portraits of Gish in the silent film era, as well as a holograph testimonial written by the author Eugene O'Neill to his wife Carlotta.

An
Additions
series is comprised of material added to the papers after 1980. Addition I consists of correspondence and legal papers involving lawsuits brought against Gish by producer Charles Duell in the 1920s. Addition II is a typed letter signed by Gish in which she provides answers to two questions about actors and acting.

arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in six series:
Arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent.
